siteDescription: Technology Executive, Modern Engineering Evangelist, and Cloud Native Architect/Engineer with a history of innovation and delivery and a focus of people, process and technology.

careerSummary.name: Seasoned IT executive
careerSummary.summary: with success in mobilizing and managing dynamic geographically diverse product engineering teams/programs.

careerSummary.name: Outcome-driven enabler
careerSummary.summary: with a proven track record of complex large scale delivery spanning technologies, clouds and industries.

careerSummary.name: Visionary innovator
careerSummary.summary: skilled at spearheading breakthrough ideas to reinvent processes, ignite disruption, and deliver scalable solutions.

careerSummary.name: Thought leader
careerSummary.summary: responsible for coaching teams, programs and organizations in modern and product engineering delivery concepts.

careerSummary.name: Hands-on engineer/architect
careerSummary.summary: with a long history in cloud native development, migration, modernization and digital transformation.

highlights.name: Accenture
highlights.summary: Led the recovery efforts across multiple critical client projects, successfully bringing them back on track while saving both Accenture and our clients tens of millions of dollars from cost overruns and quality issues.

highlights.name: Accenture
highlights.summary: Established an immersive training program focused on shifting legacy developers to cloud native engineers used both by internal Accenture teams and our clients resulting in both improved productivity (~35%) and higher retention rates (~25%).

highlights.name: Accenture
highlights.summary: Created an open-source Behavior Driven Development (BDD) test framework utilized by a variety of Accenture clients (and competitors) enabling product engineering teams to quickly and effectively test API’s using “customer” language.

highlights.name: DST Systems
highlights.summary: Led the design, development, and deployment of over 15 syndicated and 60+ custom solutions for prominent clients such as, Bank of America/Merrill Lynch, Singapore Stock Exchange, UBS and TD Ameritrade.

highlights.name: Experience, Inc.
highlights.summary: Built a first of its kind college recruiting application that used a series of custom algorithms to match students to employers for schools like Harvard, Tulane University and many others.

interestingFacts.name: Designed and developed
interestingFacts.summary: the first iteration of expedia.com (both the front and back end) with only one other engineer. This included the first near real time travel pricing engine of its kind.

interestingFacts.name: Worked as a private investigator
interestingFacts.summary: for a nationwide investigative firm, responsible for finding missing witnesses and dealing with complex insurance fraud cases.

interestingFacts.name: Coached Football, Basketball and Soccer teams
interestingFacts.summary: from kindergarten to middle-school winning a few “championships” along the way and learning a lot from the kids about what it takes to lead diverse teams.

projects.name: BDD For All
projects.description: Flexible test harness that enables teams to easily integrate Behavior - and Test - Driven Development (BDD/TDD) into their daily development while promoting automation, transparency and reporting in legacy and cloud environments.
highlights: Official Accenture OpenSource Project
Used by multiple Fortune 100 clients

projects.name: Outdoor Table
projects.description: Built based on a picture, this table was designed for six and to last the wear and tear that go along with a popular beach rental property. An outdoor, all-weather and hurricane proof (yet to be tested) has provided the setting for family meals to visitors from all over.
highlights: Designed from a picture
Built to survive extreme weather and use
Over 100 cuts joined by pocket screws and wood glue

projects.name: Reactive OpenAPI
projects.description: A reference application built with OpenAPI, Spring Reactor, & MongoDB that showcases real work implementation examples around Event Driven Architecture, Behavior Driven Development, Code Quality/Security and so much more.
highlights: Used to train teams in Spring Reactor & Event Driven Architecture
Showcases DIY code quality and security techniques
Examples of BDD in the wild
Switch between Kafka, RabbitMQ, AWS, Azure & GCP for eventing

projects.name: This Site!
projects.description: Built on React and inspired by a bunch of different tech and people, the 'Simple Resume' project is an attempt to brush up on my react skills while showcasing some other fun technologies.
highlights: Open sourced under the MIT license
Easily configured and customized all via JSON files
Written in Typescript

projects.name: Lazy Susan
projects.description: While on vacation saw a lazy susan and thought 'I could do that'.  The result is an epoxy resin beach scene with turtle handles on lazy susan built from spare wood and parts.
highlights: Built completely with leftover wood, hardware and paint
Third ever painted project (thanks Bob Ross!)

projects.name: Entryway Table
projects.description: Built for the entryway it sits in, this entryway table/cabinet was designed from a bunch of different pictures my wife liked.  Oversized and built with rustic hardware, the hardest part was to build drawers without the sliding hardware (just wood pieces)
highlights: Based on hodgepodge of pinterest ideas
Impossible to move (truly solid)

projects.name: Serverless on Azure
projects.description: Based on on publicalbum.orgs google photos embed, this python serverless function lets you embed your google photos public albums in your website seamlessly by returning a json payload ready for whatever you can dream up.
highlights: Used to help teams understand Visual Studio integration with VS Code
Showcase using lightweight functions instead of contasiners

projects.name: A Good Readme
projects.description: Going to a repo with code and no README is more common than I would of hoped.  Working with lots of different organizations I've noticed it's even more common internally.  This Gist is really about what good could look like.
highlights: Used with dozens of Fortune 50 and 100 companies as an example of how to layout
Showcase using lightweight functions instead of contasiners
